utterances: This is Teddy Thompson, the son of Richard and Linda Thompson, in duet with newcomer, Krystle Warren.
And this song's recorded live at one of a series of tribute concerts, a dozen or so musicians all playing the music of Nick Drake.
Those concerts were produced by the veteran music producer Joe Boyd, who also produced Nick Drake's first two albums back in 1969 and 1970 in England.
And yet, says, Joe, even he was surprised by the Volkswagen ad.
After this ad had such an impact and really multiplied the sales, annual sales of Nick Drake records, I met the team, the creative team who put the ad together.
And they were a bunch of, kind of, slackers from an alternative Boston ad agency.
And this guy told me that they had built the whole storyboard for the ad around a track by The Church.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""UNDER THE MILKY WAY TONIGHT"")
(Singing) Under the Milky Way tonight.

And the night before the presentation to Volkswagen, he was sitting at home smoking something and listening to ""Pink Moon."" And he suddenly had this blinding insight that this was the track, not The Church track.
And he came in the next morning and played it to the rest of the team.
He said: Let's go with this.
And at the very last minute, sort of minutes before the Volkswagen ad execs arrived, they switched the whole ad.
And that's why so many people know Nick Drake today.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""PINK MOON"")
(Singing) I saw it written and I saw it say pink moon is on its way.
And none of you stand so tall, pink moon going to get you all.
It's a pink moon.
Hey, it's a pink moon.

Let's come back to this album that you've just produced, ""Way to Blue: The Songs of Nick Drake."" You said that you were looking for people who were really comfortable doing this music, who really gave it new dimensions for you.
A lot of women perform Nick Drake songs, which I have to say I found really wonderful, Vashti Bunyan, for example.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""WHICH WILL"")
(Singing) Which will you go for?
Which will you love?
Which will you choose from, from the stars above.
Well, Vashti is a fascinating character because her story is so similar to Nick's.

You know, she was a very delicate, shy, soft-voiced singer, who I heard, actually, before Nick in the '60s - 1966 - and eventually made a record with her in 1970 which didn't sell, sold even less than Nick's.
But at one point, I introduced them to each other and tried to get them to write a song together.
And it was a complete flop because they were both so shy that neither of them said a word, I think, in the entire time they spent in a room together.
And, of course, her story is that she had a record that didn't sell.

She was living in a caravan in the outer Hebrides, had children, moved to Edinburgh, remarried, never told anyone that she'd had a career, was so crushed by the failure of the career, very much like Nick.

But then the internet came along, and she discovered there was this huge following for her one album and the, sort of, 200 copies that had been sold had been copied on tape and circulated around the world.
And eventually, it was reissued, and she's had this whole new career and a whole new following of people.
And so it just seemed perfect to have her as part of it.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""WHICH WILL"")
Senator Obama was in states where Hillary Clinton has not spent much time in recent days.

There are places, some with just a small number of delegates where he hopes to run the table, racking up win after win as a way to offset the advantages Clinton has long been perceived to have in delegate-rich Super Tuesday states like New York and California.
Obama continued to criticize Clinton for her vote to give President Bush authority to go to war in Iraq.
As for her assertion that her experience makes her ready to lead from day oneâ€¦
It's not just saying you're ready for day one, the question is, are you right on day one?
The senator told the crowd that the Democrats need a nominee who represents a clean break from President Bush on the way.
Today Obama will be in New Jersey, Connecticut, and Boston where tonight, on the eve of Super Tuesday, it's another rather and likely another big crowd.
Don Gonyea, NPR News.
And I'm Scott Horsley in Massachusetts.
Republican presidential hopeful John McCain campaigns today here in the home state of his chief rival, Mitt Romney.
Yesterday McCain was in Connecticut where he held a rally with another senator, Independent Democrat, Joe Lieberman at his side.
Thank you to the state of Connecticut.
We will win Connecticut.
I will get the nomination of my party, and I will campaign in this state.
Lieberman, like McCain, is a staunch supporter of the war in Iraq.
The two men were briefly interrupted by anti-war protesters in the audience, but the hecklers were quickly shouted down when McCain supporters started shouting, Mac is back.
(soundbite of chanting)
My friends, I know America is divided over this war.
I heard our friends there yelling and I respect their views.
But let me also say to you, my dear friends, no American is divided in our support of the brave young men and women who are serving this country in the United States military today.
McCain dropped in later on a Boston bar that reportedly once served as a hangout for Paul Revere.
He wound up the evening watching some Latter Day Patriots play the New York Giants.
After review, the Giants had 12 men on the field.
McCain's keeping his fingers crossed that by Wednesday there will be fewer players left standing on the Republican field.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Boston.
I'm Audie Cornish with the Mitt Romney campaign.
In his final push, Romney's appealing to his supporter's love of Ronald Reagan and distrust of Senator John McCain.
I'll tell you what we need to have is a person who will stand up for the principles of the Republican Party, live in the house that Ronald Reagan built, and win the White House again.
With a one-two punch that won over Christine Bowles and Gretchen Bowles Perlberg(ph) at a rally of several hundred in Glen Ellyn, Illinois.
I think he's great.
I think he's our hope.
He's our hope for the future of America.
He's by far the best.
The fact that he wants a small tiny government and the people need to be the one, we're hiring them, they're not telling us what to do.
That's what we want.
After a pause in campaigning to mourn the death of Mormon leader Gordon Hinckley in Utah, Romney took his campaign through Minnesota, Illinois, and Missouri.
He made a last minute pitch in a St. Louis bar just before the Super Bowl kick-off.
I'm gonna keep on fighting to get this nomination, I need your help, you guys have to go out there and vote as many times as you can.
Take your friends and do it, and we're gonna win on Tuesday.
Thank you.
The former Massachusetts governor the night in Tennessee where he watched his New England Patriots lose the Super Bowl in a Nashville hotel bar.
Romney is scheduled a last-minute stop in Long Beach for tonight, even though he has events on the east coast tomorrow morning.
The red-eye flight could be worth it.
California's 170 delegates are by far the biggest GOP prize in the primaries.
Audie Cornish, NPR News.
I'm Robert Smith.
Mike Huckabee's weekend schedule looked like a list of tour dates for a Lynyrd Skynyrd cover band.
Memphis, Huntsville, Tuscaloosa, and even when he made it to Macon, Georgia, the soundtrack at the rallies stayed the same.
(Soundbite of ""Sweet Home Alabama"")
Huckabee has failed to win a single contest since Iowa.
And since money's tight, he's falling back on his southern roots.
I know how to cook grits, I know how to fry a catfish, I don't eat fried chicken with the skin off and with a knife and fork.
That last reference was a dig at the healthy eating habits of Mitt Romney who has become quite the punching bag for this campaign.
Mike Huckabee rarely mentions John McCain, but all weekend he was telling Romney, southern man, don't need him 'round anyhow.
One of my opponents in this race today was on television.
He actually had the audacity to suggest that I should drop out of the race.
Huckabee then reminded the crowd that Romney has spent millions of dollars of his own fortune on the race.
I want to make real sure that he understands something.
This old Arkansas boy is not for sale.
He doesn't have enough money to buy me.
I'm not a trouble company that he can buy, sell off the assets, and send us home.
But Huckabee says he isn't leaving until somebody clinches the nomination.
About the quarter of the delegates to be awarded tomorrow are in the south, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Georgia, Tennessee, and Alabama.
And Huckabee says they're trying to win them all.
Robert Smith, NPR News, Macon, Georgia.
And you can find out what's at stake on Super Tuesday as NPR.org/elections.
Plus you can check back there tomorrow night for special coverage including results and real time analysis.
Go ahead please.
Hundreds spent the night in emergency shelters.
Two died in the flood waters in southern Vermont and two more are feared dead.
Both the missing are workers for the city of Rutland who were checking out the municipal water system when they were swept away.
Vermont's roads follow the river valleys, so the heaviest damage was to roadways and bridges.
Transportation Secretary Brian Searles says the state is just beginning to assess the destruction.
And the list that I've been presented of closures on the state and local system looks to be about 260.
I don't think we've ever experienced anything quite like that.
